htmlEmbed:
Is Metaverse Fashion Week The Future Of Fashion?Cond√© Nast3/2/2022

The first fashion week held in the metaverse featured virtual collections by Etro, Dundas, and Auroboros, as well an appearance from Grimes.

fashion, web, tagsRead

</script><script></script><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"It‚Äôs undeniable that the hot topic of the moment is the metaverse. When [Decentraland](https://decentraland.org/) hosted the first ever Metaverse Fashion Week last weekend, the industry‚Äôs interest was piqued. Did it deliver everything to an optimal standard? Much may have been left to be desired, but there‚Äôs hope for the future.\n\n‚ÄúWeb3 and the metaverse serve as complements to fashion activations IRL,‚Äù Giovanna Graziosi Casimiro, head of Metaverse Fashion Week, tells *Vogue*. ‚ÄúInstead of pitting the two against each other, brands should embrace both spaces and use them to amplify their brand narrative and reach new audiences.‚Äù Featuring a roster of labels ranging from the established, such as [Etro](https://www.vogue.co.uk/tags/etro), [Dundas](https://www.vogue.co.uk/tags/dundas), Dolce & Gabbana, and Elie Saab, to the more independent likes of [Imitation of Christ](https://imitationofchristofficial.com/), [Gary McQueen](https://www.garyjamesmcqueen.com/), and [Auroboros](https://www.auroboros.co.uk/), the schedule was packed with notable virtual moments to delve into. But each had an agenda of their own in the metaverse.\n\n+++group-2\n\n[#image: /photos/6247002f142999edd5990595]|||‚ÄúPutting the show together was easy and not as hectic as a ‚Äòreal‚Äô one, but it was equally exciting,‚Äù says Etro‚Äôs creative director Veronica Etro.|||\n\n\n\n[#image: /photos/6247002e967796fe3ad49bed]|||A metaverse design in Etro‚Äôs signature paisley.|||\n\n+++\n\nEtro hosted a show in Decentraland‚Äôs fashion arena where looks on avatars wore realistic iterations of the label‚Äôs signature paisley print. The Italian brand saw entering the metaverse as a way to access younger generations and reach a wider audience. ‚ÄúPutting the show together was easy and not as hectic as a ‚Äòreal‚Äô one, but it was equally exciting,‚Äù explains creative director Veronica Etro. ‚ÄúA lot of effort went into the technology, there‚Äôs so much human work behind it all\\! I think that such immersive experiences are now part of entertainment ‚Äì a sort of bridge between e-commerce, social media and gaming. I am confident that it will gain more importance in the years to come.‚Äù\n\n\n\n[#image: /photos/62470105967796fe3ad49bf5]|||The view from the FROW of the Dundas show.|||\n\nPartaking in MVFW felt like a natural follow up to Dundas‚Äôs [first NFT after the Super Bowl](https://www.vogue.com/article/mary-j-blige-super-bowl-halftime-look-peter-dundas). Not only did the brand host a fashion show, a pop-up store was also created featuring its panther print codes. ‚ÄúThe metaverse is here to stay, so partaking in the MVFW was exciting and an evolution of Dundas‚Äôs disruptor DNA,‚Äù explains creative director Peter Dundas. ‚ÄúIt is still important to create a link between the metaverse and the physical world, so my partner and I approached it like any physical show in terms of creating the looks, music, and backdrop, even styling the avatars. It‚Äôs an exciting extension of fashion that‚Äôs limitless for the imagination. Plus, it‚Äôs completely sustainable.‚Äù\n\n\n\n[#image: /photos/624700ff3eea7c3bca8e83b9]|||Outside the Imitation of Christ space.|||\n\nInstead of a traditional runway format, Imitation of Christ opted to showcase its pieces in an immersive exhibition with looks strewn across an impressively lit space. The American brand wanted to focus on their collaborative efforts with the likes of director Adam Teninbaum, Nicole Buffett (yes, Warren Buffett‚Äôs granddaughter), Lynsey Addario, and Bored Apes Yacht Club [a platform for unique NFTs living on the Ethereum blockchain]. ‚ÄúWe remain hopeful that supporting each other and building community is what younger people are focused on,‚Äù says Imitation of Christ designers Matthew Damhave and Tara Subkoff over email. ‚ÄúWe hope this inclusiveness and support can be mirrored back IRL.‚Äù\n\n\n\n[#image: /photos/624701563eea7c3bca8e83ed]|||A peek inside Gary McQueen‚Äôs store.|||\n\nAs this is not Gary McQueen‚Äôs first virtual rodeo ‚Äì the brand released an entirely digital collection last year ‚Äì dipping a toe into the metaverse was more of a natural progression for the independent label. The designer, whose creations exist primarily as 3D assets, champions digital as the future of fashion beyond the conventional industry space. ‚ÄúThere will always be a need for physical clothing, but I think it‚Äôs important to understand that the metaverse is something totally different from what traditional thinkers understand as fashion,‚Äù says McQueen. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more about self-expression and identity, as well as a way to connect and communicate within a platform that is totally community driven without the infringement of hierarchy.‚Äù\n\n\n\n[#image: /photos/62470104a9719eefd6292a46]|||Grimes causing a commotion at the closing event of MVFW.|||\n\nTo cap off the schedule, emerging digital-first brand Auroboros joined forces with musician Grimes. ‚ÄúWe first connected with Grimes after she DM-ed us in 2021, so the idea for a collaboration has been in the works for a while,‚Äù explained co-creative directors Alissa Aulbekova and Paula Sello over email. ‚ÄúYounger generations are more likely to have participated in digital media from an early age and therefore have a greater understanding of the virtual world as digital natives. Also, many advancements in technology and digitalisation have facilitated young talents to be spotted and appreciated for their creativity.‚Äù\n\nThe overall verdict on MVFW? Attendance was noticeably sparse from industry insiders, and without high-functioning computers, experiences were hindered. As *Vogue* Runway‚Äôs [Luke Leitch put it](https://www.vogue.com/article/metaverse-fashion-week-decentraland): ‚ÄúBasically you need one of those weird-looking *Battlestar Galactica*\\-styled gaming PC‚Äôs with a monstrous graphics card to get the best out of the metaverse.‚Äù However, as always, trial and error is essential for progress. Next time, maybe there‚Äôll be a larger turnout to not only support brands ‚Äì especially emerging ones ‚Äì but also to help future-proof the industry in an increasingly digital world.\n\n\n\n[#article: /articles/6242bd41967796fe3ad4982b]","articleSection":"fashion","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Alex Kessler","sameAs":"https://www.vogue.co.uk/profile/alex-kessler"}],"dateModified":"2022-04-02T12:44:57.145+01:00","datePublished":"2022-04-02T12:44:57.145+01:00","headline":"Is Metaverse Fashion Week data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p>It‚Äôs undeniable that the hot topic of the moment is the metaverse. When <a data-offer-url="https://decentraland.org/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://decentraland.org/"}" href="https://decentraland.org/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Decentraland</a> hosted the first ever Metaverse Fashion Week last weekend, the industry‚Äôs interest was piqued. Did it deliver everything to an optimal standard? Much may have been left to be desired, but there‚Äôs hope for the future.</p><p>‚ÄúWeb3 and the metaverse serve as complements to fashion activations IRL,‚Äù Giovanna Graziosi Casimiro, head of Metaverse Fashion Week, tells <em>Vogue</em>. ‚ÄúInstead of pitting the two against each other, brands should embrace both spaces and use them to amplify their brand narrative and reach new audiences.‚Äù Featuring a roster of labels ranging from the established, such as <a href="https://www.vogue.co.uk/tags/etro">Etro</a>, <a href="https://www.vogue.co.uk/tags/dundas">Dundas</a>, Dolce & Gabbana, and Elie Saab, to the more independent likes of <a data-offer-url="https://imitationofchristofficial.com/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://imitationofchristofficial.com/"}" href="https://imitationofchristofficial.com/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Imitation of Christ</a>, <a data-offer-url="https://www.garyjamesmcqueen.com/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.garyjamesmcqueen.com/"}" href="https://www.garyjamesmcqueen.com/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Gary McQueen</a>, and <a data-offer-url="https://www.auroboros.co.uk/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.auroboros.co.uk/"}" href="https://www.auroboros.co.uk/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">Auroboros</a>, the schedule was packed with notable virtual moments to delve into. But each had an agenda of their own in the metaverse.</p><div class="GroupCalloutWrapper-dhzjud jXcbpf callout callout--group callout--group-2" data-testid="GroupCalloutWrapper"><figure </span><span class="BaseWrap-sc-TURhJ BaseText-fFzBQt CaptionCredit-cTdqxu eTiIvU nZFKf iHbDSe caption__credit">Courtesy of Etro</span></div></figure></div><p>Etro hosted a show in Decentraland‚Äôs fashion arena where looks on avatars wore realistic iterations of the label‚Äôs signature paisley print. The Italian brand saw entering the metaverse as a way to access younger generations and reach a wider audience. ‚ÄúPutting the show together was easy and not as hectic as a ‚Äòreal‚Äô one, but it was equally exciting,‚Äù explains creative director Veronica Etro. ‚ÄúA lot of effort went into the technology, there‚Äôs so much human work behind it all! I think that such immersive experiences are now part of entertainment ‚Äì a sort of bridge between e-commerce, social media and gaming. I am confident that it will gain more importance in the years to come.‚Äù</p><div class="ConsumerMarketingUnitThemedWrapper-kkMeXf hBFNZw consumer-marketing-unit Not only did the brand host a fashion show, a pop-up store was also created featuring its panther print codes. ‚ÄúThe metaverse is here to stay, so partaking in the MVFW was exciting and an evolution of Dundas‚Äôs disruptor DNA,‚Äù explains creative director Peter Dundas. ‚ÄúIt is still important to create a link between the metaverse and the physical world, so my partner and I approached it like any physical show in terms of creating the looks, music, and backdrop, even styling the avatars. It‚Äôs an exciting extension of fashion that‚Äôs limitless for the imagination. Plus, it‚Äôs completely sustainable.‚Äù</p><div class="AdWrapper-fFweuL dIvDeZ ad ad--in-content"><div class="ad__slot ad__slot--in-content" data-node-id="sbuy3"></div></div><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-iLfYbx iclJOW asset-embed"><div class="AssetEmbedAssetContainer-fogSSF kRpSOB asset-embed__asset-container"><span class="SpanWrapper-kGGzGm fCMktE responsive-asset AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-eqsnW ehcXJi asset-embed__responsive-asset"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-jIKgcS fArnhQ AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-eqsnW ehcXJi asset-embed__responsive-asset responsive-image"><noscript><img alt="Image may contain Human and Person" class="ResponsiveImageContainer-dlOMGF dnUTOP responsive-image__image" src="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/624700ff3eea7c3bca8e83b9/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/ioc_DCL_stills_00032.jpg" srcSet="https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/624700ff3eea7c3bca8e83b9/master/w_120,c_limit/ioc_DCL_stills_00032.jpg 120w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/624700ff3eea7c3bca8e83b9/master/w_240,c_limit/ioc_DCL_stills_00032.jpg 240w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/624700ff3eea7c3bca8e83b9/master/w_320,c_limit/ioc_DCL_stills_00032.jpg 320w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/624700ff3eea7c3bca8e83b9/master/w_640,c_limit/ioc_DCL_stills_00032.jpg 640w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/624700ff3eea7c3bca8e83b9/master/w_960,c_limit/ioc_DCL_stills_00032.jpg 960w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/624700ff3eea7c3bca8e83b9/master/w_1280,c_limit/ioc_DCL_stills_00032.jpg 1280w, https://media.vogue.co.uk/photos/624700ff3eea7c3bca8e83b9/master/w_1600,c_limit/ioc_DCL_stills_00032.jpg 1600w" sizes="100vw"/></noscript></picture></span></div><div class="CaptionWrapper-brisHk ixilfU caption AssetEmbedCaption-eXYFag iEqAnV asset-embed__caption"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-TURhJ BaseText-fFzBQt CaptionText-cOFJqa eTiIvU lOrEx hTa-dbB caption__text"><p>Outside the Imitation of Christ space.</p>
</span><span class="BaseWrap-sc-TURhJ BaseText-fFzBQt CaptionCredit-cTdqxu eTiIvU nZFKf iHbDSe caption__credit">Courtesy of Imitation of Christ.</span></div></figure><p>Instead of a traditional runway format, Imitation of Christ opted to showcase its pieces in an immersive exhibition with looks strewn across an impressively lit space. The American brand wanted to focus on their collaborative efforts with the likes of director Adam Teninbaum, Nicole Buffett (yes, Warren Buffett‚Äôs granddaughter), Lynsey Addario, and Bored Apes Yacht Club [a platform for unique NFTs living on the Ethereum blockchain]. ‚ÄúWe remain hopeful that supporting each other and building community is what younger people are focused on,‚Äù says Imitation of Christ designers Matthew Damhave and Tara Subkoff over email. ‚ÄúWe hope this inclusiveness and support can be mirrored back IRL.‚Äù</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buSdEM caption__text"><p>A peek inside Gary McQueen‚Äôs store.</p>
</span><span class="BaseWrap-sc-TURhJ BaseText-fFzBQt CaptionCredit-cTdqxu eTiIvU nZFKf iHbDSe caption__credit">Courtesy of Gary McQueen</span></div></figure><p>As this is not Gary McQueen‚Äôs first virtual rodeo ‚Äì the brand released an entirely digital collection last year ‚Äì dipping a toe into the metaverse was more of a natural progression for the independent label. The designer, whose creations exist primarily as 3D assets, champions digital as the future of fashion beyond the conventional industry space. ‚ÄúThere will always be a need for physical clothing, but I think it‚Äôs important to understand that the metaverse is something totally different from what traditional thinkers understand as fashion,‚Äù says McQueen. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more about self-expression and identity, as well as a way to connect and communicate within a platform that is totally community driven without the infringement of hierarchy.‚Äù</p><figure class="AssetEmbedWrapper-iLfYbx iclJOW asset-embed"><div class="AssetEmbedAssetContainer-fogSSF kRpSOB asset-embed__asset-container"><span class="SpanWrapper-kGGzGm fCMktE responsive-asset AssetEmbedResponsiveAsset-eqsnW ehcXJi caption__text"><p>Grimes causing a commotion at the closing event of MVFW.</p>
</span><span class="BaseWrap-sc-TURhJ BaseText-fFzBQt CaptionCredit-cTdqxu eTiIvU nZFKf iHbDSe caption__credit">Courtesy of Auroboros.</span></div></figure><p>To cap off the schedule, emerging digital-first brand Auroboros joined forces with musician Grimes. ‚ÄúWe first connected with Grimes after she DM-ed us in 2021, so the idea for a collaboration has been in the works for a while,‚Äù explained co-creative directors Alissa Aulbekova and Paula Sello over email. ‚ÄúYounger generations are more likely to have participated in digital media from an early age and therefore have a greater understanding of the virtual world as digital natives. Also, many advancements in technology and digitalisation have facilitated young talents to be spotted and appreciated for their creativity.‚Äù</p><div class="Container-imGeBO ftlPuP"></div><p>The overall verdict on MVFW? Attendance was noticeably sparse from industry insiders, and without high-functioning computers, experiences were hindered. As <em>Vogue</em> Runway‚Äôs <a href="https://www.vogue.com/article/metaverse-fashion-week-decentraland">Luke Leitch put it</a>: ‚ÄúBasically you need one of those weird-looking <em>Battlestar Galactica</em>-styled gaming PC‚Äôs with a monstrous graphics card to get the best out of the metaverse.‚Äù However, as always, trial and error is essential for progress. Next time, maybe there‚Äôll be a larger turnout to not only support brands ‚Äì especially emerging ones ‚Äì but also to help future-proof the industry in an increasingly digital world.</p><div first fashion week held in the metaverse featured virtual collections by Etro, Dundas, and Auroboros, as well an appearance from Grimes.","head.keywords":"fashion","head.og.type":"article","head.robots":"index, follow, max-image-preview:large","head.title":"Is Metaverse Fashion Week The Future Of Fashion? | British Vogue","tenant":"vogue-uk","head.social.title":"Is Metaverse Fashion Week The Future Of The Industry?","head.social.description":"Many emerging designers say yes.","head.promo.dek":"The first fashion week held in the metaverse featured virtual collections by Etro, Dundas, and Auroboros, as well an appearance from Grimes.","head.social.opinion":"false","head.jsonld":[{"@context":"http:\u002F\u002Fschema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"It‚Äôs undeniable that the hot topic of the moment is the metaverse. When [Decentraland](https:\u002F\u002Fdecentraland.org\u002F) hosted the first ever Metaverse Fashion Week last weekend, the industry‚Äôs interest was piqued. Did it deliver everything to an optimal standard? Much may have been left to be desired, but there‚Äôs hope for the future.\n\n‚ÄúWeb3 and the metaverse serve as complements to fashion activations IRL,‚Äù Giovanna Graziosi Casimiro, head of Metaverse Fashion Week, tells *Vogue*. ‚ÄúInstead of pitting the two against each other, brands should embrace both spaces and use them to amplify their brand narrative and reach new audiences.‚Äù Featuring a roster of labels ranging from the established, such as [Etro](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.co.uk\u002Ftags\u002Fetro), [Dundas](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.co.uk\u002Ftags\u002Fdundas), Dolce & Gabbana, and Elie Saab, to the more independent likes of [Imitation of Christ](https:\u002F\u002Fimitationofchristofficial.com\u002F), [Gary McQueen](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.garyjamesmcqueen.com\u002F), and [Auroboros](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.auroboros.co.uk\u002F), the schedule was packed with notable virtual moments to delve into. But each had an agenda of their own in the metaverse.\n\n+++group-2\n\n[#image: \u002Fphotos\u002F6247002f142999edd5990595]|||‚ÄúPutting the show together was easy and not as hectic as a ‚Äòreal‚Äô one, but it was equally exciting,‚Äù says Etro‚Äôs creative director Veronica Etro.|||\n\n\n\n[#image: \u002Fphotos\u002F6247002e967796fe3ad49bed]|||A metaverse design in Etro‚Äôs signature paisley.|||\n\n+++\n\nEtro hosted a show in Decentraland‚Äôs fashion arena where looks on avatars wore realistic iterations of the label‚Äôs signature paisley print. The Italian brand saw entering the metaverse as a way to access younger generations and reach a wider audience. ‚ÄúPutting the show together was easy and not as hectic as a ‚Äòreal‚Äô one, but it was equally exciting,‚Äù explains creative director Veronica Etro. ‚ÄúA lot of effort went into the technology, there‚Äôs so much human work behind it all\\! I think that such immersive experiences are now part of entertainment ‚Äì a sort of bridge between e-commerce, social media and gaming. I am confident that it will gain more importance in the years to come.‚Äù\n\n\n\n[#image: \u002Fphotos\u002F62470105967796fe3ad49bf5]|||The view from the FROW of the Dundas show.|||\n\nPartaking in MVFW felt like a natural follow up to Dundas‚Äôs [first NFT after the Super Bowl](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.com\u002Farticle\u002Fmary-j-blige-super-bowl-halftime-look-peter-dundas). Not only did the brand host a fashion show, a pop-up store was also created featuring its panther print codes. ‚ÄúThe metaverse is here to stay, so partaking in the MVFW was exciting and an evolution of Dundas‚Äôs disruptor DNA,‚Äù explains creative director Peter Dundas. ‚ÄúIt is still important to create a link between the metaverse and the physical world, so my partner and I approached it like any physical show in terms of creating the looks, music, and backdrop, even styling the avatars. It‚Äôs an exciting extension of fashion that‚Äôs limitless for the imagination. Plus, it‚Äôs completely sustainable.‚Äù\n\n\n\n[#image: \u002Fphotos\u002F624700ff3eea7c3bca8e83b9]|||Outside the Imitation of Christ space.|||\n\nInstead of a traditional runway format, Imitation of Christ opted to showcase its pieces in an immersive exhibition with looks strewn across an impressively lit space. The American brand wanted to focus on their collaborative efforts with the likes of director Adam Teninbaum, Nicole Buffett (yes, Warren Buffett‚Äôs granddaughter), Lynsey Addario, and Bored Apes Yacht Club [a platform for unique NFTs living on the Ethereum blockchain]. ‚ÄúWe remain hopeful that supporting each other and building community is what younger people are focused on,‚Äù says Imitation of Christ designers Matthew Damhave and Tara Subkoff over email. ‚ÄúWe hope this inclusiveness and support can be mirrored back IRL.‚Äù\n\n\n\n[#image: \u002Fphotos\u002F624701563eea7c3bca8e83ed]|||A peek inside Gary McQueen‚Äôs store.|||\n\nAs this is not Gary McQueen‚Äôs first virtual rodeo ‚Äì the brand released an entirely digital collection last year ‚Äì dipping a toe into the metaverse was more of a natural progression for the independent label. The designer, whose creations exist primarily as 3D assets, champions digital as the future of fashion beyond the conventional industry space. ‚ÄúThere will always be a need for physical clothing, but I think it‚Äôs important to understand that the metaverse is something totally different from what traditional thinkers understand as fashion,‚Äù says McQueen. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more about self-expression and identity, as well as a way to connect and communicate within a platform that is totally community driven without the infringement of hierarchy.‚Äù\n\n\n\n[#image: \u002Fphotos\u002F62470104a9719eefd6292a46]|||Grimes causing a commotion at the closing event of MVFW.|||\n\nTo cap off the schedule, emerging digital-first brand Auroboros joined forces with musician Grimes. ‚ÄúWe first connected with Grimes after she DM-ed us in 2021, so the idea for a collaboration has been in the works for a while,‚Äù explained co-creative directors Alissa Aulbekova and Paula Sello over email. ‚ÄúYounger generations are more likely to have participated in digital media from an early age and therefore have a greater understanding of the virtual world as digital natives. Also, many advancements in technology and digitalisation have facilitated young talents to be spotted and appreciated for their creativity.‚Äù\n\nThe overall verdict on MVFW? Attendance was noticeably sparse from industry insiders, and without high-functioning computers, experiences were hindered. As *Vogue* Runway‚Äôs [Luke Leitch put it](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.vogue.com\u002Farticle\u002Fmetaverse-fashion-week-decentraland): ‚ÄúBasically you need one of those weird-looking *Battlestar Galactica*\\-styled gaming PC‚Äôs with a monstrous graphics card to get the best out of the metaverse.‚Äù However, as always, trial and error is essential for progress. Next time, maybe there‚Äôll be a larger turnout to not only support brands ‚Äì especially emerging ones ‚Äì but also to help future-proof the industry in an increasingly digital readabilityObject.title: Is Metaverse Fashion Week The Future Of Fashion?
readabilityObject.content:
It‚Äôs undeniable that the hot topic of the moment is the metaverse. When Decentraland hosted the first ever Metaverse Fashion Week last weekend, the industry‚Äôs interest was piqued. Did it deliver everything to an optimal standard? Much may have been left to be desired, but there‚Äôs hope for the future.

‚ÄúWeb3 and the metaverse serve as complements to fashion activations IRL,‚Äù Giovanna Graziosi Casimiro, head of Metaverse Fashion Week, tells Vogue. ‚ÄúInstead of pitting the two against each other, brands should embrace both spaces and use them to amplify their brand narrative and reach new audiences.‚Äù Featuring a roster of labels ranging from the established, such as Etro, Dundas, Dolce & Gabbana, and Elie Saab, to the more independent likes of Imitation of Christ, Gary McQueen, and Auroboros, the schedule was packed with notable virtual moments to delve into. But each had an agenda of their own in the metaverse.

Etro hosted a show in Decentraland‚Äôs fashion arena where looks on avatars wore realistic iterations of the label‚Äôs signature paisley print. The Italian brand saw entering the metaverse as a way to access younger generations and reach a wider audience. ‚ÄúPutting the show together was easy and not as hectic as a ‚Äòreal‚Äô one, but it was equally exciting,‚Äù explains creative director Veronica Etro. ‚ÄúA lot of effort went into the technology, there‚Äôs so much human work behind it all! I think that such immersive experiences are now part of entertainment ‚Äì a sort of bridge between e-commerce, social media and gaming. I am confident that it will gain more importance in the years to come.‚Äù

Partaking in MVFW felt like a natural follow up to Dundas‚Äôs first NFT after the Super Bowl. Not only did the brand host a fashion show, a pop-up store was also created featuring its panther print codes. ‚ÄúThe metaverse is here to stay, so partaking in the MVFW was exciting and an evolution of Dundas‚Äôs disruptor DNA,‚Äù explains creative director Peter Dundas. ‚ÄúIt is still important to create a link between the metaverse and the physical world, so my partner and I approached it like any physical show in terms of creating the looks, music, and backdrop, even styling the avatars. It‚Äôs an exciting extension of fashion that‚Äôs limitless for the imagination. Plus, it‚Äôs completely sustainable.‚Äù

Instead of a traditional runway format, Imitation of Christ opted to showcase its pieces in an immersive exhibition with looks strewn across an impressively lit space. The American brand wanted to focus on their collaborative efforts with the likes of director Adam Teninbaum, Nicole Buffett (yes, Warren Buffett‚Äôs granddaughter), Lynsey Addario, and Bored Apes Yacht Club [a platform for unique NFTs living on the Ethereum blockchain]. ‚ÄúWe remain hopeful that supporting each other and building community is what younger people are focused on,‚Äù says Imitation of Christ designers Matthew Damhave and Tara Subkoff over email. ‚ÄúWe hope this inclusiveness and support can be mirrored back IRL.‚Äù

As this is not Gary McQueen‚Äôs first virtual rodeo ‚Äì the brand released an entirely digital collection last year ‚Äì dipping a toe into the metaverse was more of a natural progression for the independent label. The designer, whose creations exist primarily as 3D assets, champions digital as the future of fashion beyond the conventional industry space. ‚ÄúThere will always be a need for physical clothing, but I think it‚Äôs important to understand that the metaverse is something totally different from what traditional thinkers understand as fashion,‚Äù says McQueen. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more about self-expression and identity, as well as a way to connect and communicate within a platform that is totally community driven without the infringement of hierarchy.‚Äù

To cap off the schedule, emerging digital-first brand Auroboros joined forces with musician Grimes. ‚ÄúWe first connected with Grimes after she DM-ed us in 2021, so the idea for a collaboration has been in the works for a while,‚Äù explained co-creative directors Alissa Aulbekova and Paula Sello over email. ‚ÄúYounger generations are more likely to have participated in digital media from an early age and therefore have a greater understanding of the virtual world as digital natives. Also, many advancements in technology and digitalisation have facilitated young talents to be spotted and appreciated for their creativity.‚Äù

The overall verdict on MVFW? Attendance was noticeably sparse from industry insiders, and without high-functioning computers, experiences were hindered. As Vogue Runway‚Äôs Luke Leitch put it: ‚ÄúBasically you need one of those weird-looking Battlestar Galactica-styled gaming PC‚Äôs with a monstrous graphics card to get the best out of the metaverse.‚Äù However, as always, trial and error is essential for progress. Next time, maybe there‚Äôll be a larger turnout to not only support brands ‚Äì especially emerging ones ‚Äì but also to help future-proof the industry in an increasingly digital world.

jsonLd.headline: Is Metaverse Fashion Week The Future Of Fashion?
jsonLd.description: The first fashion week held in the metaverse featured virtual collections by Etro, Dundas, and Auroboros, as well an appearance from Grimes.
jsonLd.articleBody:
It‚Äôs undeniable that the hot topic of the moment is the metaverse. When [Decentraland](https://decentraland.org/) hosted the first ever Metaverse Fashion Week last weekend, the industry‚Äôs interest was piqued. Did it deliver everything to an optimal standard? Much may have been left to be desired, but there‚Äôs hope for the future.

‚ÄúWeb3 and the metaverse serve as complements to fashion activations IRL,‚Äù Giovanna Graziosi Casimiro, head of Metaverse Fashion Week, tells *Vogue*. ‚ÄúInstead of pitting the two against each other, brands should embrace both spaces and use them to amplify their brand narrative and reach new audiences.‚Äù Featuring a roster of labels ranging from the established, such as [Etro](https://www.vogue.co.uk/tags/etro), [Dundas](https://www.vogue.co.uk/tags/dundas), Dolce & Gabbana, and Elie Saab, to the more independent likes of [Imitation of Christ](https://imitationofchristofficial.com/), [Gary McQueen](https://www.garyjamesmcqueen.com/), and [Auroboros](https://www.auroboros.co.uk/), the schedule was packed with notable virtual moments to delve into. But each had an agenda of their own in the metaverse.

+++group-2

[#image: /photos/6247002f142999edd5990595]|||‚ÄúPutting the show together was easy and not as hectic as a ‚Äòreal‚Äô one, but it was equally exciting,‚Äù says Etro‚Äôs creative director Veronica Etro.|||



[#image: /photos/6247002e967796fe3ad49bed]|||A metaverse design in Etro‚Äôs signature paisley.|||

+++

Etro hosted a show in Decentraland‚Äôs fashion arena where looks on avatars wore realistic iterations of the label‚Äôs signature paisley print. The Italian brand saw entering the metaverse as a way to access younger generations and reach a wider audience. ‚ÄúPutting the show together was easy and not as hectic as a ‚Äòreal‚Äô one, but it was equally exciting,‚Äù explains creative director Veronica Etro. ‚ÄúA lot of effort went into the technology, there‚Äôs so much human work behind it all\! I think that such immersive experiences are now part of entertainment ‚Äì a sort of bridge between e-commerce, social media and gaming. I am confident that it will gain more importance in the years to come.‚Äù



[#image: /photos/62470105967796fe3ad49bf5]|||The view from the FROW of the Dundas show.|||

Partaking in MVFW felt like a natural follow up to Dundas‚Äôs [first NFT after the Super Bowl](https://www.vogue.com/article/mary-j-blige-super-bowl-halftime-look-peter-dundas). Not only did the brand host a fashion show, a pop-up store was also created featuring its panther print codes. ‚ÄúThe metaverse is here to stay, so partaking in the MVFW was exciting and an evolution of Dundas‚Äôs disruptor DNA,‚Äù explains creative director Peter Dundas. ‚ÄúIt is still important to create a link between the metaverse and the physical world, so my partner and I approached it like any physical show in terms of creating the looks, music, and backdrop, even styling the avatars. It‚Äôs an exciting extension of fashion that‚Äôs limitless for the imagination. Plus, it‚Äôs completely sustainable.‚Äù



[#image: /photos/624700ff3eea7c3bca8e83b9]|||Outside the Imitation of Christ space.|||

Instead of a traditional runway format, Imitation of Christ opted to showcase its pieces in an immersive exhibition with looks strewn across an impressively lit space. The American brand wanted to focus on their collaborative efforts with the likes of director Adam Teninbaum, Nicole Buffett (yes, Warren Buffett‚Äôs granddaughter), Lynsey Addario, and Bored Apes Yacht Club [a platform for unique NFTs living on the Ethereum blockchain]. ‚ÄúWe remain hopeful that supporting each other and building community is what younger people are focused on,‚Äù says Imitation of Christ designers Matthew Damhave and Tara Subkoff over email. ‚ÄúWe hope this inclusiveness and support can be mirrored back IRL.‚Äù



[#image: /photos/624701563eea7c3bca8e83ed]|||A peek inside Gary McQueen‚Äôs store.|||

As this is not Gary McQueen‚Äôs first virtual rodeo ‚Äì the brand released an entirely digital collection last year ‚Äì dipping a toe into the metaverse was more of a natural progression for the independent label. The designer, whose creations exist primarily as 3D assets, champions digital as the future of fashion beyond the conventional industry space. ‚ÄúThere will always be a need for physical clothing, but I think it‚Äôs important to understand that the metaverse is something totally different from what traditional thinkers understand as fashion,‚Äù says McQueen. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more about self-expression and identity, as well as a way to connect and communicate within a platform that is totally community driven without the infringement of hierarchy.‚Äù



[#image: /photos/62470104a9719eefd6292a46]|||Grimes causing a commotion at the closing event of MVFW.|||

To cap off the schedule, emerging digital-first brand Auroboros joined forces with musician Grimes. ‚ÄúWe first connected with Grimes after she DM-ed us in 2021, so the idea for a collaboration has been in the works for a while,‚Äù explained co-creative directors Alissa Aulbekova and Paula Sello over email. ‚ÄúYounger generations are more likely to have participated in digital media from an early age and therefore have a greater understanding of the virtual world as digital natives. Also, many advancements in technology and digitalisation have facilitated young talents to be spotted and appreciated for their creativity.‚Äù

The overall verdict on MVFW? Attendance was noticeably sparse from industry insiders, and without high-functioning computers, experiences were hindered. As *Vogue* Runway‚Äôs [Luke Leitch put it](https://www.vogue.com/article/metaverse-fashion-week-decentraland): ‚ÄúBasically you need one of those weird-looking *Battlestar Galactica*\-styled gaming PC‚Äôs with a monstrous graphics card to get the best out of the metaverse.‚Äù However, as always, trial and error is essential for progress. Next time, maybe there‚Äôll be a larger turnout to not only support brands ‚Äì especially emerging ones ‚Äì but also to help future-proof the industry in an increasingly digital world.
